awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Plant discovery in the southern Philippines
awd_abstract_narration:
The Philippines archipelago, comprising over 7500 islands, is known to contain high levels of unique plant and animal diversity but several of the islands, especially Visayas and Mindanao in the south of the country, still need to be intensively sampled. Many animal and plant species, including potential crop plants, await discovery and description even as extensive areas are threatened by deforestation. This four-year project will document and describe land plant and lichen diversity in the southern Philippines through a series of large field expeditions followed by taxonomic study and formal description. The project team will document the occurrence and abundance of diverse plant species through a combination of physical museum collections and high-resolution photographs. All images and locality data will be placed online in easily searchable formats. The project will also develop a DNA repository of collections made during the field expeditions for future genealogical studies. Project data will be used to assemble species inventories in different areas of the southern Philippines to both identify biodiversity hotspots and prioritize land management decisions. Diverse training in field and laboratory methods will be provided to undergraduate and graduate researchers in Texas and North Carolina to prepare them for diverse science careers. U.S. high school students will learn about biodiversity through a project-based curriculum that includes exposure to collections, digital data, and spatial analysis. Outreach, including online interactive programs through the Botanical Research Institute of Texas (BRIT), will disseminate research findings broadly within the U.S. and the Philippines to both scientists and the public.

This botanical survey of the southern Philippines will be conducted through eight major field expeditions. Herbarium specimens will be digitized and freely disseminated along with associated metadata and images of both living in-situ and museum specimens derived from the collections generated by the project.  Collections will be analyzed using a combination of morphological and molecular systematic approaches to produce a diversity of taxonomic products, including revisions, regional annotated checklists, and multi-entry keys. Project data will be used to characterize patterns of species richness and endemism and test biogeographic hypotheses associated with the effect of Pleistocene land conformations on the Philippine flora. The project will discover new species, rediscover poorly known species, and document new species records for the Philippines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project Plant and Lichen Discovery in the Southern Philippines was a seven-year survey and inventory of the land plants (bryophytes and vascular plants) and lichens of selected areas of the southern Philippines, funded by an award of $1.2 million from the National Science Foundation Directorate for Biological Sciences. The grant was co-awarded to the Botanical Research Institute of Texas (BRIT) at the Fort Worth Botanic Garden and the University of North Carolina Wilmington, with key participation from researchers at the California Academy of Sciences, Missouri Botanical Garden, National Museum of Natural History (NMNH), and other institutions. The major in-country partner in the Philippines was the Center for Biodiversity Research and Extension in Mindanao at Central Mindanao University, with contributions by the National Museum of the Philippines, Bukidnon State University, University of the Philippines, and other organizations.

The Philippines contains a stunning level of plant and lichen species diversity. Nonetheless, this diversity is still poorly documented scientifically and severely threatened by habitat loss through human activities. The project prioritized the survey of high-quality forest that are either at imminent risk of destruction or which have high potential for preservation through ongoing efforts of land stewards. The project most intensively focused on central Mindanao, where most of the high peaks of the island occur but which are still not adequately explored. Other islands surveyed were Camiguin, Dinagat, and Negros. Additional general fieldwork was conducted in the islands of Luzon and Palawan by project students while focusing on their research taxa. Examples of focal areas are dormant volcanic peaks, including Mt. Apo, the highest point in the Philippines; cloud forests, including  so-called bonsai vegetation, a unique assemblage of stunted trees; forest over limestone; ultramafic areas, which harbor rare and endemic plants due to high levels of naturally occurring heavy metals in the soil; low-elevation coastal forests; and low-elevation dipterocarp forests, now nearly eliminated.

Six major expeditions were conducted, along with several minor expeditions, either as pre-expedition reconnaissance, or by small groups of Filipino researchers to areas for which access is not allowed by foreign participants. Each major expedition was one-month in duration and consisted of 30 to 40 team members, including senior researchers, graduate and undergraduate students, the leaders and staff of local partner government entities, community parataxonomists and guides, and local base camp support teams. On each expedition, the project team divided into focus groups for lichens, bryophytes, ferns, and seed plants. Data and specimen collection varied by focus group but generally constituted specimen collection numbers with several duplicates, tissue collections dried in silica gel for potential later extraction of high-quality DNA, detailed photographs of each vascular plant and many lichens and bryophytes, standardized data on habitats and specimen features recorded for collection labels, and photo- and video-documentation of expedition proceedings.

Over the course of the project, an estimated 15,000 lichen, 14,000 bryophyte, and 6700 vascular plant collection numbers were made. With duplicates included, the total number of specimens collected was well over 100,000. Specimens are being deposited at most of the participating institutions and distributed to other institutions with major collections. As the specimens are studied, they and their associated data can be expected to contribute to a new wealth of knowledge regarding the plants and lichens of the southern Philippines for many years to come. Several species new to science have been documented, and many more have undoubtedly been collected and await confirmation or discovery by specialists. Many new species records to specific islands have been made, as well as the rediscovery of species only known from a single specimen (the type material). Finally, field guides and area species lists of various groups have been produced. Tissue samples were collected in duplicate for all vascular plants and are or will be deposited at BRIT and NMNH through the Global Genome Biodiversity Network. The population of the data into a searchable web portal (https://philippines.botanicaldiscovery.org) is ongoing. The data on the portal include digitized images of the prepared specimens, live-specimen photographs taken in the field, and searchable label data.

The project has generated 28 peer-reviewed papers, with many more submitted or planned. Over 25 presentations at scientific meetings and other scientific and more popular venues have been delivered in the U.S. and the Philippines, and five workshops and three symposia were delivered at Philippine institutions. The project included an intensive capacity-building component, with two Filipino students obtaining their M.Sc. degree at U.S. institutions, and two students in Ph.D. programs in the U.S. Project personnel also served on committees for five other graduate students obtaining their degree in the Philippines, and U.S. participant institutions hosted nine project faculty and their students for training and collaboration during extended visits. Dozens more Filipino students and local participants were trained informally in field methods and in plant and lichen identification during expeditions.
